Federal judge won’t stop NC’s 12-week abortion ban from starting July 1




By: Lynn Bonner - June 28, 2023 5:15 pm


























  
 L. Richardson Preyer Federal Courthouse in Greensboro (Photo: Lynn Bonner) 





U.S.  District Court Judge Catherine Eagles was clear Wednesday that she would not put a freeze on the state’s recently enacted 12-week abortion ban, meaning that most of the restrictions will take effect July 1. 
Planned Parenthood South Atlantic and a Duke University OB/GYN sued to stop the law from taking effect, at least temporarily. Brigitte Amiri, the ACLU lawyer representing Duke OB/GYN Beverly Gray, asked Eagles Wednesday to put a hold on the entire law. Eagles said she wouldn’t, calling the request “overbroad relief.”
What Eagles will do with some of the abortion providers’ specific complaints are a different matter. They’re tied up not only by lawyers’ differing views of what the law says, but also with the timing of changes the legislature made in response to the lawsuit. It’s possible Gov. Roy Cooper will veto the bill containing the corrections, so the abortion law’s mistakes would be in force for a while. Or, Cooper could sign the clean-up bill before Saturday, meaning that a federal court order putting some of the law’s changes on hold wouldn’t be needed. 
“If I do agree, a narrow injunction is appropriate,” Eagles said. “Probably, I do have to do something if the Governor doesn’t act. How that should be worded, I don’t exactly know.”
Eagles said she would have a decision by Friday. Most of the law takes effect Saturday. It bans most abortions after 12 weeks, with exceptions for rape, incest, “life-limiting fetal anomalies” and emergencies. 
The legislature this week passed a bill clearing up in the law. For example, a change made it clear that medication abortions will be allowed through 12 weeks. The clean-up bill received final legislative votes on Tuesday.   
The House sent that to Gov. Roy Cooper, but as of Wednesday afternoon, he had not signed it. If he decides to veto it, there may be two weeks or more during which some of the problematic provisions would be in effect. 
The legislature would likely override a veto, said Ellis Boyle, the attorney representing Republican legislative leaders. Cooper has until July 7 to sign the bill or veto it, Boyle said. He could also announce it will become law without his signature. If Cooper decides to veto the bill, the veto would take two to four weeks to override, Boyle said. He was accounting for legislators’ July vacations. (Some recent veto overrides have been accomplished in a much shorter time frame.)
A lag would mean that provisions abortion providers said were vague or contradictory, and that the legislature meant to change, would be in force for weeks. 
Opposing lawyers did not agree that some of the legislature’s changes went far enough.
The legislature changed the law this week, with Republicans explaining that they intended to say it is okay to give someone advice on how to get a legal out-of-state abortion after 12 weeks’ gestation.
“North Carolina can’t stop someone from driving a person to another state after 12 weeks,” Boyle said.
Lawyers for abortion providers say the law still has problems. 
On Monday, the Senate rejected a proposed change to the clean-up bill that Democrats offered that would make it clear that people can help women seeking out-of-state abortions. 
“We are in a different world where there is heightened concern about the use of statutes to go after abortion providers,” Amiri said. 
Boyle and the abortion providers’ lawyers hold different positions on a section of the law requiring a provider prescribing abortion pills to document that the pregnancy is in the uterus using an ultrasound. 
Boyle said the requirements were to ensure that someone with an ectopic pregnancy — where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus — isn’t given abortion pills. They shouldn’t be used with ectopic pregnancies, according to the FDA. 
“It’s dangerous to give abortion pills when there is an ectopic pregnancy,” he said. 
Peter Im, the Planned Parenthood of America lawyer, said some people seeking abortion pills don’t have gestational sacs visible in ultrasounds. They may have miscarriages after positive pregnancy test results, or may be seeking pills so early in pregnancy that gestational sacs aren’t visible, he said.
The law “prohibits providing medication abortion for pregnancy of unknown location,” Im said. “Medication abortion can safely be provided for pregnancy of unknown location.”
